comment: At 7:10 or so you mention that increasing reactants would increase Q to be larger than K, and shift our reaction to the right. The shift to right is correct, but in the equation of Q = [products] / [reactants] wouldn't increasing reactant concentration mean the Q would then be less than K, and make a shift to the right?
after the reaction oppose the change wil it returns to the equilibrium state?
thank you! right on the point
Thanks for the quick response! Thanks for the video

Just to clear up any confusion. If I were to instead add a gas molecule that actually does participate, then I would be increasing pressure of only one side. For example, if i increase pressure by adding nitrogen, then the left side would increase in pressure. This means that the reaction would shift to the right, thereby decreasing pressure. Note that this is due to entropy. Entropy always tends to even out a system under stress.

Hey! You would be increasing pressure! But you are increasing pressure evenly on both side. Entropy dictates that in this case, since both side increase by the same amount of pressure, nothing will happen! The system is already at highest entropy!
If you were to add Cl2 as you said at the end would you not be increasing pressure therefore causing a shift in equilibrium to the right?
I second this. Isn't that a mistake?
Yes it is! Sorry, forgot to add the subscript.
stareofthedragon adding Cl2 at constant volume will not change the partial pressure of  the reactant molecules so no effect on equilibrium
